items.title: BBC says IDF murdered children and lied about it
items.content_html:
‘The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) says the building was targeted because it was a Hezbollah “terrorist command centre” and it “eliminated” a Hezbollah commander. It added that “the overwhelming majority” of those killed in the strike were “confirmed to be terror operatives”.

‘But a BBC Eye investigation verified the identity of 68 of the 73 people killed in the attack and uncovered evidence suggesting just six were linked to Hezbollah’s military wing. None of those we identified appeared to hold a senior rank. The BBC’s World Service also found that the other 62 were civilians - 23 of them children.’
items.content_text:
'The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) says the building was targeted because it was a Hezbollah "terrorist command centre" and it "eliminated" a Hezbollah commander. It added that "the overwhelming majority" of those killed in the strike were "confirmed to be terror operatives". 'But a BBC Eye investigation verified the identity of 68 of the 73 people killed in the attack and uncovered evidence suggesting just six were linked to Hezbollah's military wing. None of those we identified appeared to hold a senior rank. The BBC's World Service also found that the other 62 were civilians - 23 of them children.'
IDF said bombed apartments were Hezbollah base - but most of dead were civilians bbc.com
Home - BBC News https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cgrn0nwn0eqo

items.title: Life lessons
items.content_html:
On Sunday I was listening to Lianne La Havas' COLORS rendition of “Bittersweet” on YouTube.

We‚Äôre picking that fight everyday
This shit‚Äôs going nowhere

The Algorithm did its job well and showed me the latest KEXP concert by a new to me band called English Teacher. I was blown away.

Even though I’ve seen more COLORS Shows than KEXPs

A bit prog at times, and a lot music studenty, but they can really play so that’s all forgiven, especially if you listen to the interview with the band at the end of the full concert.

“Albert Road” is possibly my favourite, although I think the recorded version is even better and more poignant with the video (especially in light of the drama of the last couple of days):

(Steve’s mate’s son used to play in The Fall…)

So don’t take our prejudice to heart
We hate everyone
The world around us never showed
How loving can be fun

More than The Fall, they somehow remind me of The Sugarcubes, who I loved back in the late 80s, but who I haven’t listened to properly for a long time. I listened to the album “Life’s Too Good” this afternoon while working, and it was better than I remember it. “Deus":

He put me in a bath tub
Made me squeaky clean

Apparently Bjork’s producer produced English Teacher’s album.

More reminiscent of The Fall (and Frank Sidebottom), perhaps, is their song (and video) about the singer’s smalltown hometown of Colne in Lancashire and its inflated egos, “The World’s Biggest Paving Slab”.

I am the world’s biggest paving slab
So watch your fucking feet
items.content_text:
On Sunday I was listening to Lianne La Havas' COLORS rendition of "[Bittersweet](https://youtu.be/_YOvQNgpfXY)" on YouTube. 

>We‚Äôre picking that fight everyday  
>This shit‚Äôs going nowhere

The Algorithm did its job well and showed me the latest KEXP concert by a new to me band called [English Teacher](https://youtu.be/Qeo4GZMe-FE). I was blown away. 

>Even though I've seen more COLORS Shows than KEXPs  

A bit prog at times, and a lot music studenty, but they can really play so that's all forgiven, especially if you listen to the interview with the band at the end of the full concert.

"[Albert Road](https://youtu.be/OPm0hwBbtnI)" is possibly my favourite, although I think the recorded version is even better and more poignant with the video (especially in light of the drama of the last couple of days):

>(Steve's mate's son used to play in The Fall...)  

>So don't take our prejudice to heart  
>We hate everyone  
>The world around us never showed  
>How loving can be fun  

More than The Fall, they somehow remind me of The Sugarcubes, who I loved back in the late 80s, but who I haven't listened to properly for a long time. I listened to the album "Life's Too Good" this afternoon while working, and it was better than I remember it. "[Deus](https://youtu.be/fq2dWTBVZD4)":

>He put me in a bath tub  
>Made me squeaky clean  

Apparently Bjork's producer produced English Teacher's album.

More reminiscent of The Fall (and Frank Sidebottom), perhaps, is their song (and video) about the singer's smalltown hometown of Colne in Lancashire and its inflated egos, "[The World's Biggest Paving Slab](https://youtu.be/YNkbgumvYyA)".

>I am the world's biggest paving slab  
>So watch your fucking feet

items.content_html: I had a really poor night’s sleep, worrying about little kid.
items.content_text: I had a really poor night's sleep, worrying about [little kid](https://davidmarsden.info/2025/01/23/little-kid-slept-in-his.html).

items.content_html: Little kid slept in his own bed until 6 am. Hurrah!
items.content_text: Little kid slept in his own bed until 6 am. Hurrah!
